title: A Christmas Without Jesus
description:
What happens when the symbol of Jesus no longer represents kindness, compassion, or love? In this deeply honest Christmas message, Britt Hartley explains why this is the first year she has chosen to remove Jesus entirely from her home‚Äîand why she believes it may actually honor the historical Jesus more authentically. From religious trauma to nationalism, this video explores how Christianity‚Äôs modern meaning has shifted, and why letting go can sometimes be the most faithful act.

The conversation also tackles the Santa question head-on: Do we lie to our kids? Do we replace religion with consumerism? Using real-world examples‚Äîfrom scientific skepticism to storytelling traditions‚Äîthis video invites parents and families to reflect on their core values and make intentional choices. Whether you‚Äôre religious, secular, or somewhere in between, this message challenges you to rethink what Christmas really stands for.

title: Is Christianity Secretly Gay?
description:
Is Christianity actually about God‚Äîor is it about men bonding with other men? In this video, we unpack a provocative but deeply researched question: why Christianity reserves its deepest loyalty, devotion, and emotional intimacy for men‚Äîwhile women are reduced to support roles. Drawing from feminist theory, religious history, and modern Christian nationalism, this breakdown explores how patriarchal religion functions as a homosocial system rather than a spiritually inclusive one.

We examine male hero worship, the erasure of the divine feminine, Christian purity culture, and why figures like Nick Fuentes unintentionally reveal Christianity‚Äôs emotional subtext. From medieval monasteries to modern men‚Äôs ministries, this video explains why women often leave Christianity feeling unseen‚Äîand why Christian nationalism is panicking as women reclaim autonomy, embodiment, and spiritual authority.

description:

title: From Deepak Chopra to Wim Hof: When Wellness Turns Dangerous
description:
America has quietly become the Wild West of spirituality, and Deepak Chopra is my case study for why that‚Äôs so dangerous. In this video, I walk through Chopra‚Äôs long-running misuse of science terms like ‚Äúquantum healing,‚Äù his public claims about curing cancer with consciousness, and the newly released Jeffrey Epstein emails that show a disturbingly friendly relationship even after Epstein was a registered sex offender. I also cover anonymous allegations from a former client at the Chopra Center and why all of this points to a much larger crisis in the spiritual but not religious world, not just one ‚Äúbad guru.‚Äù

From unregulated ayahuasca and psychedelic retreats, to wellness influencers telling people to quit meds, to manifestation coaches blaming poverty on ‚Äúlow vibrations,‚Äù to sexual abuse in yoga and meditation communities, I map out how the U.S. has almost zero guardrails for spiritual work outside of organized religion. I share my own ethical limits as a spiritual director, how I try to avoid becoming a guru, and why you‚Äîthe listener‚Äîare now the de facto ethics committee for spirituality. If you care about deconstruction, religious trauma, wellness culture, or finding healthy spiritual guidance, this is your crash course in how to spot red flags before they ruin lives.

title: Viral Baby Formula TikTok Exposes Church Hypocrisy
description:
A crying baby, a desperate mom, and 40 cold calls to churches and houses of worship: that‚Äôs the viral social experiment that suddenly has everyone questioning whether U.S. churches are still earning their tax-exempt status. In this video, we walk through TikTok creator Nicki n Ali Monroe‚Äôs baby formula experiment, where she calls churches asking for one single can of formula‚Äîand documents who says yes, who says no, and what that reveals about Christian nationalism, church wealth, and real-world compassion. From white Christian churches refusing to help non-members, to instant yeses from a mosque, a Buddhist temple, and Black churches, this story exposes a brutal gap between pro-life rhetoric and actual aid to a hungry child.

Using this viral moment as a case study, we zoom out to the bigger picture: the quiet collapse of trust in organized religion, the political marriage between church and state, and why many young people‚Äîespecially Gen Z women‚Äîare walking away from Christianity altogether. We connect the dots between church tax breaks, lack of transparency, global examples of regulating religious orgs, and historical parallels like the Catholic Church‚Äôs sale of indulgences leading to the Protestant Reformation. If you‚Äôve ever wondered whether churches still provide the social safety net they claim‚Äîor what might replace them when they don‚Äôt‚Äîthis video breaks it down with history, data, and a candid look at what‚Äôs shifting inside American Christianity right now.

description:

title: The Autism and Nihilism Connection
description:

This episode unpacks the lived connection between autism, rumination, depressive realism, and suicidal thinking‚Äîand why ‚Äújust think positive‚Äù advice often backfires. You‚Äôll learn a structured, evidence-aligned approach to move from spirals to action using acceptance and commitment therapy, body reconnection, executive-function supports, and justice-driven micro-agency.

We break down 10 practical interventions tailored for neurodiverse cognition: autistic-affirming connection (without masking), ACT and mindfulness for rumination, rebuilding interoception to fight anhedonia, channeling moral sensitivity into tangible service, protecting executive function and rest, sleep and sensory hygiene, permission to go deep on your interests, non-verbal risk monitoring, and pairing existential philosophy with embodied action. If you‚Äôve felt like therapy was gaslighting‚Äîor that the math of suffering ‚Äúwins‚Äù‚Äîthis is your toolkit to build a life you‚Äôre glad to experience.

title: What Psychologists Get WRONG About Nihilism
description:
Nihilism gets thrown around in therapy and in headlines‚Äîbut psychologists and philosophers mean very different things. In this video, Brit Hartley breaks down the mismatch: how clinicians often use ‚Äúnihilism‚Äù to describe a state of hopelessness or burnout, while philosophers use it to describe a claim about reality and meaning. That gap can make therapy feel invalidating for people with existential or ‚Äúrational‚Äù nihilism‚Äîand it explains why ‚Äúfind joy‚Äù or basic reframing can fall flat.

You‚Äôll learn a practical two-axis way to locate yourself (psychological state √ó philosophical stance), why CBT and ‚Äúgratitude only‚Äù approaches often underperform for philosophical nihilism, and how existentially trained therapists and philosophical counseling can help. We also separate nihilism from accelerationism, highlight UK models that integrate philosophy and therapy, and set up Part 2 with concrete tools to ask for the help you actually need.

title: Why People Don‚Äôt Trust Atheists #Atheism #Morality #ReligionAndSociety
description:
Religious people often give more through congregational networks, but studies show it‚Äôs the social connections, not belief itself, that predict generosity. Historically, belief in God worked like a social contract‚Äîa way to trust strangers in large societies before modern justice systems.

This evolutionary background explains why many still distrust atheists: ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt believe in God, what keeps you from cheating me?‚Äù Yet data reveals that atheists are often just as generous, and sometimes kinder to people outside their own group. The challenge today is finding new ways to signal morality without religion‚Äîthrough philosophy, civic duty, or secular ethics.

title: Do Atheists Give More to Charity? #Atheism #Charity  #Mormon
description:
Studies show that religious people report higher levels of volunteering and charitable giving‚Äîbut most of it stays within their own communities, often under pressure from their church. For example, Mormons give 10% of their income as tithing, but less than 1% of church funds go to humanitarian aid.

Atheists, on the other hand, may give less overall, but when they do, it often goes to secular charities, disaster relief, or causes outside their own group. The data reveals: generosity isn‚Äôt about belief‚Äîit‚Äôs about where the pressure and values are directed.

title: Be Seen #Vulnerability #Connection #MentalHealth #Loneliness #RealTalk #BeSeen

Transcript:
Is now learning how to be alone together,  which is through vulnerability  and the slow art of letting yourself be seen.  So existential loneliness can feel especially  sharp when we're around people.  But we still feel unknown. We still feel like we're just  playing a game or wearing a mask.  And that's because being in a room with others doesn't touch the ache of.  Of not of. Of being seen.  Right?  You can be partnered, you can be social, you can be popular, and you can still be starved for real connection  if you're never  offering your  world to anyone else.  And vulnerability  is our best antidote for that. Not just sharing your pain, but letting someone see your joy and your weirdness and your questions and your contradictions. And it's slow work  because we've been taught to hide our true selves in order to stay safe or stay loved.  But you.  But when you find someone you can be real with,  even in small doses, that ache really softens.  And you don't need.  You don't need big groups to be able to practice. This vulnerability can begin in really low stakes spaces.  A comment on a post that's more  honest than usual because it's a private Facebook group.  A voice note to a friend where you say how you really feel.  Being in a therapist  session where you're not performing  every time you reveal  instead of conceal, you chip away at this illusion of separateness.  And because existential loneliness wants us to believe that we're in these isolated universes spinning silently.  But vulnerability is going to be the  bridge  that.  That can  connect us.  And the more you let yourself  be seen,  the more likely that there's someone out there that goes, oh, me too.

title: You Will Die Alone #Existentialism #Nihilism #MentalHealthAwareness #Loneliness
description:
You‚Äôre never truly alone! 
Even in a room full of people, your experience is uniquely yours. 
Embrace the truth of existential loneliness. 

It's it's this experience of aloneness at the core of your being  that no one,  no one really knows what it's like to be you.  You're in a room full of people. Even the reason that this is so hard is that you can be in a room full of people who care about you,  and you realize that no one will ever fully know what it's like to be you.  No God, no person, no parent,  no soulmate will ever really know  what it's like to be you.  You will die alone no matter how many people you have around you.  You will die alone. And the way that you see the world and the way that you experience the world is so unique to  you,  it will die with you. That's existential loneliness.  And so sometimes, like I said earlier, the hardest part of existential crisis  is not what you're going through, but having to  go through it alone. There's a difference between being in prison  and being  able to be in gen  pop  and being in prison in isolation.  So for me personally, what this looked like was when I was  kind  of  spent my time in the deepest part of the void.  Total nihilism. No meaning  to  live  suicidal ideation.  I can't tell anyone about it because I don't want to drag someone into the void. Like if I really cared.  Like if someone I really cared about wanted to  sit down with me for eight hours  while they listened to my thoughts, where I destroyed their religion and their God and their sense of self and their free  will, and their belief in soulmates and their patterns and whatever. He also says that they should be conservative. But I'm going to focus on the religious part.  And  at first glance, it sounds elitist  that  only  stupid people are religious, which is not what he's saying, because he's a big fan of religion.  It's more of a pragmatic claim.  So he's arguing that if you're not going to reinvent the moral wheel yourself, if you're not going to construct an ethical system from scratch,  actually probably safer for you to plug into a tradition  that already  gives you meaning and community  and rituals and guardrails and things that are good for humans. title: Nietzsche mourning God's death #Nietzsche #Philosophy #Existentialism
description:

Transcript:
He wasn't cheering when he said, God is dead. He was mourning.  To  Nietzsche,  the the death of God wasn't just the loss of a theological figure,  it was the collapse  of the moral architecture that had propped up Western civilization. So God, for Nietzsche,  was this linchpin  of meaning and morality and metaphysics. And when you take him out,  the whole structure is going to fall apart.  So Nietzsche  wasn't naive.  He didn't think that people would just calmly accept the death of God and then just  like,  build new secular systems of values overnight.  He was deeply pessimistic that we would be  able to  survive this.  He believed that most people would  either double down  on fundamentalism,  fall into  nihilism,  or latch on  to  dangerous replacements like nationalism or some kind of  totalitarian ideology.  And he was right about that.  Like  like  all those three  he was right about. Like if someone I really cared about wanted to  sit down with me for eight hours  while they listened to my thoughts, where I destroyed their religion and their God and their sense of self and their free  will, and their belief in soulmates and their patterns and whatever. And I  destroyed it all. I wouldn't even want to do that because I think they're happier in their delusional story. So it's this feeling that I hear from so many nihilists that I meet with  who say,  I learn too much.  I see things that I never should  have seen.  Now, I can't be in relationships with other people,  and I don't even want them to  know these things about reality, because they're happier without that knowledge.  And when we  hit that part of nihilism, we can see  either suicide, suicide ideation or slow suicide, which is just lots of numbing  behaviors  in order to  cope with  the combination of.  There being no meaning and purpose,  and also that there's no one to even talk to.  About it. And even further than that,  we don't even want to talk to  people about it, because you almost want to protect them  from these harsh realities  that they don't know about yet,  because maybe they're happier in their delusion or story. So it's the combination of no meaning and purpose, not talking  to anyone about it, and not even  being  able to  talk to anyone about it because you don't even want them to be  where you are.

title: Were the Founding Fathers REALLY Christian?

From Thomas Jefferson's rejection of Christian dogma to James Madison's fierce defense of church-state separation, we explore the deist, skeptical, and secular roots of the men who built the foundation of the United States. If you've ever heard people say "the Founding Fathers were Christian," this breakdown of history and direct quotes will give you the truth behind the myth.

We‚Äôll also explore how Christian nationalism has distorted American history, why prayer proclamations were politically motivated, and how figures like George Washington and Benjamin Franklin saw religion as a useful societal tool‚Äînot as divine truth. Whether you're a history buff, atheist, skeptic, or curious believer, this video will challenge what you think you know about America‚Äôs founding and the real relationship between religion and government.

title: The Film Heretic Reveals the Dark Side of Religion vs Secularism
description:
In this video, I dive into the thought-provoking movie Heretic and explore its fascinating themes through the lens of secular spirituality and religious deconstruction. As an ex-Mormon and a scholar of world religions, I couldn‚Äôt help but connect deeply with the movie‚Äôs central question: Which door do you choose‚Äîbelief or disbelief?

I break down the most compelling scene of the film, where the characters confront the similarities between world religions. Is religion a human attempt to reach God‚Äîor a reflection of our own fears and needs? What happens when we realize these recurring myths‚Äîlike virgin births, resurrection, and chosen people‚Äîmight not point to divine truth but to our shared humanity?

You‚Äôre faced with a terrifying question: belief or disbelief? This video dives deep into the provocative movie Heretic, exploring the existential choice between religious belief and nihilism. What happens when religion isn't true but still fulfills human needs for meaning, community, and purpose? Discover how secularism struggles to replace what religion provides and why humanity clings to collective myths despite their flaws. The terrifying alternative: Without religion, are we left only with nihilism, chaos, and the brutal indifference of nature?

title: Are You Nihilistic or Just Depressed?
description:
In this video, atheist spiritual director Britt Hartley explores one of the most challenging questions in existentialism: "Are you nihilistic, or are you just depressed?" Britt shares her personal journey through deep nihilism, suicidal ideation, and existential dread, describing what it was like to feel trapped in a world without inherent meaning.
